title: Who will win Austria's upcoming presidential election?
preds: Unless I have seriously misread practically everything, this election is as over as any election could possibly aspire to be.  I am glad of the result, although I guessed it dead wrong.  (I guessed the US one and several others dead wrong as well, but was not glad.  These things happen.)

From FT's (Dec. 6, p.3): "To try to build the Freedom Party's respectability, Mr. (Heinz-Christian) Strache said it would not challenge the result....."No Freedom party members are gathering for demos, no stones will be thrown, nothing is burning - that's democracy" .... Austria seems to have lived up to it's pro-European reputation.  Hofer puts responsibility for loss on People's party leader, R. Mitterlehner's support for Van deer Bellen.  Social Dems may be interested in a coalition gov't. With FP after the next Parliamentary election.

Austrian voters roundly rejected on Sunday a candidate vying to become the first freely elected far-right head of state in Europe since World War Two, halting at least temporarily the wave of populism sweeping Western democracies. The runoff vote was a litmus test, since it was a re-run of a vote held in May, before Britain voted to leave the European Union and Americans elected Donald Trump as president. Norbert Hofer of the anti-immigration Freedom Party lost the May election by less than a percentage point, and polls had for months shown the race too close to call. But within minutes of polls closing it was clear he had lost to former Greens leader Alexander Van der Bellen, who had put the June Brexit referendum at the center of his campaign, saying Hofer would lead Austria down the same road as Britain and warning voters not to "play with this fire".
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-austria-election-idUSKBN13S0W0 So much for the Trump wave.
Strange that the question is not closed yet after yesterday's election outcome.
Van der Bellen has a 6 pt lead.
Because the election was today and polls are coming out.... wrong closing date of question

Offial now: Dear friend!
I thank you. You have supported me so magnificently and I am infinitely sad that it did not work out. I would have liked to take care of our Austria.
Alexander Van der Bellen congratulated me on his success and asked all Austrians to keep together and work together. We are all Austrians, no matter how we chose the electorate.
Long live our home Austria.
Your
Norbert Hofer

Calculation: Van der Bellen wins the election
Alexander Van der Bellen is unobtainable in the election to the German President before his FPÖ competitor Norbert Hofer. This is the result of the ORF calculation of the SORA Institute. According to this, Van der Bellen comes to 53.6 percent, Hofer to 46.4 percent. The first detailed results show that Van der Bellen was able to increase slightly in many municipalities compared to the first election.

Shift toward the right continues. With the win by Trump, this has made it ok for more individuals who felt peer pressure against the right otherwise, to disregard said pressures and vote for the right.

Beebs say "too close to call"... link here http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-38198694 In final debate the 45 year old Hoffer called his year old green opponent "liar" 24 times.  Hofer wants to improve relations with the Kremlin, a meme that also has political currency in neighboring Germany.

Tough one. Most polls (Latest Nov. 17) have Hofer up by 1-3 points. On the other hand most polls were by Gallup which had Hofer up by 6 points ten days before the last election (which ended 50-50). If they have the same bias this time around then A.VdB should win. On the other hand, if the wave of right-wing populism pushes Hofer supporters to the polls in greater numbers, then add another right wing populist to the global cocktail.

The media is talking about this election as if Hofer has already won.  I wonder what impact that will have on voters:  Will that impel Van der Bellen's voters to go to the polls to prevent what the media is seeming to suggest will happen?  make Hofer's supporters complacent and cause the election to go to Van der Bellen?  Or will Van der Bellen's voters think "What's the use?" and stay home?    I am trying to separate my hopes from my expectations.
I have a minimal expectation that Hofer will win:  51%
I have a significant hope that Van der Bellen will win.   Accurate forecasters do not allow their hopes to influence their forecasts unless they think that the voters will do the same.  I have no idea what Austrian voters are thinking and how they might respond to media reports.  So, I should flip my forecast to Hofer.  Question:  Should the incredible happen and this election, too, be voided, will it resolve as "None of the above"?

There is a growing trend against the EU and in favor of sovereignty. The establishment rigging of the votes will rally more voters in favor of Herr Hofer. The elite obviously tone death and refuses to change. If you don't adapt, soon you will become extinct.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Austrian_presidential_election,_2016 According to Wikipedia, the most recent poll gave Van der Bellen the edge by 1%, but the 4 prior polls in November gave the edge to Hofer at 51 or 52%. Out of hope, I've added 1% to the most recent poll results for Van der Bellen.

While generally reported as "too close to call" am confirming the previous forecast.    
Reasons: 
-  Hofer has consistently polled slightly ahead of Van der Bellen however as mentioned related to the recent US election, polls may be underestimating support for Hofer due to the "far-right" media reports and unwillingness of supporters to be insulted/labelled. 
- Key issues include immigration (1):  Hofer wants to ban economic migrants, while Van Bellen calls for faster integration.   A recent report of "sharia police" (2) in Germany  suggests integration may be more difficult than Van Bellen suggests.
CLIP: 
" What are the key issues?
Hofer has focussed on the EU’s migration crisis and called for a ban on economic migrants.
Austria – a nation of 8.7 million – has taken in more than 120,000 migrants from the Middle East, Africa and Asia since last year, bearing much of the burden of the influx together with Germany and Sweden.
Van der Bellen has called for faster integration of recognised asylum seekers." 1:   http://www.euronews.com/2016/11/28/all-you-need-to-know-about-austria-s-presidential-election
2:   http://www.thelocal.de/20161122/sharia-police-are-not-illegal-rules-german-court - EU Stance (1):   Van Bellen is pro-EU.   Hofer in contrast is less supportive, saying that certain circumstances, for example Turkey becoming a member of efforts to centralize more power in EU headquarters (Brussels) 
A recent survey found 37% of Austrians had a negative outlook towards Brussels  -  The presidential position is largely ceremonial (1), and so could be considered an effective method of sending a message of discontent to Brussels while limiting any possible impact on the country.
Polls extremely close, last election was extremely close, Hofer has very slight lead in current polls but *also did last time* before he lost narrowly. About as pure a tossup as you'll ever see...

I wish I could come up with a convincing reason to change this, but I can't--unless there is hope in the fact that I have been more consistently wrong about elections this year than in any year since 1956.  Stay tuned.

Van der Bellen won the first vote in May by a tight margin.  Since then we have seen success for the right with Brexit and the election of Trump. This may have no impact but could swing some floating voters. Recent polls show Hofer ahead. The viral video from a holocaust survivor may have some impact but that was the perception after the murder of Jo Cox MP in Britain but this didn't seem to significantly affect the outcome. This feels close but on the basis of the polls and the trend in recent elections elsewhere I'm forecasting Hofer as slightly more likely.
Depends heavily on who will mobilize their voters the most. At the moment it seems to be the FPÖ

Polls continue to look very similar to the polls before the previous vote in May when Van der Bellen narrowly won (I won't speculate on whether voting irregularities had any impact one way or another).  It's hard to say whether Brexit or the US election will have any impact on anyones voting intentions (my guess would be that it is minimal).  As I stated in a previous forecast, the number of votes cast per capita was higher in districts in which Hofer won in the May election.  I don't know how this corresponds to actual turnout of eligible voters, but it still suggests that Van der Bellen has a larger pool of non-voters that he has an opportunity to try to turn out for the December vote.
The right-wing party of Hofer has momentum due to Brexit and the Trump victory. His followers are motivated to go to vote.

In three weeks, Austria will go to the polls once more to decide whether independent candidate Alexander van der Bellen or far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) candidate Norbert Hofer should be the new president. In the first installment back in June, the result of which was annulled by the country’s constitutional court due to postal vote anomalies, the margin between the two men was just 0.6%. Over the summer, there was little movement in the opinion polls between the two candidates. Much like his far-right counterparts across Europe, FPÖ leader Heinz-Christian Strache declared himself a fan of President-Elect Donald Trump, meaning the bandwagon is rapidly filling up. Strache has already pimped Hofer has a potential middleman between the US and Russia. However, the uncertainties that have already emerged regarding Trump’s forthcoming stint in the Oval Office may convince the electorate to stick with the traditional parties and figures, rather than plumping to elect Europe’s first far-right head of state since the Second World War. Pollsters have already become more cautious. No one has been too eager to predict what the outcome of the rerun will be, especially since Trump’s win defied most of the forecasts that were made before the 8 November vote. Both Austrian candidates are currently hovering around the 50% mark.
On the back of measures taken by the Austrian government, immigration is no longer the hot topic it was before the summer and is not the catalyst it once was for the FPÖ. Nevertheless, integration will still play a significant role in people’s election choice.
http://www.eurasiareview.com/14112016-could-austrias-presidential-election-be-hit-by-trump-effect/

Perhaps the Trump effect will occur here? He is slightly in the lead there.
Hofer's had a fairly consistent but slight lead, & of course the banter heuristic predicts he'll win

Hofer has a slight lead in the polls and the anti-immigration rhetoric has gathered pace in Austria since the annulled second round back in May. Feel also that the US election result might encourage some fence sitters to take the more conservative stance. Not ruling out the possibility that the opposite will be true, i.e. that there will be a liberal backlash in Europe to ensure the same result does not take place on the other side of the Atlantic.

Van der Bellen means for most people "establishment" in comparison to Hofer. Bellen stood for change in comparison to Kohl, Hundstorfer etc., but not in comparison to Hofer. And most people want change. So easily some stories about afghans or syrians raping somebody, or some new corruption scandals, etc etc, and people tend to Hofer. Instead, nobody can deliver new reasons to vote for Bellen, the Brexit won't reveal negative effects on Britain till the election, neither can Trumps election.
After Trump and Brexit the excitement of the far-right might tip the balance...
Emboldened Right will be more enthusiastic?
A reelection reenergizes Hofners campaign more than it does van der Bellens.
Up significantly on Norbert riding Trump's worldwide cotails and the rising world wide tide of right-wing reactionary populist authoritarianism.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrian_presidential_election,_2016 Polls show close to zero difference.

I made the prior forecast based on the following reasoning: The polls said Hofer was ahead 51% to 49%. The polls in the US are correct around 2/3 of the time (http://www.gallup.com/poll/9442/election-polls-accuracy-record-presidential-elections.aspx). So from this, Hofer has a 66% chance of winning. I decreased that to 58% since many of the accurate polls were a predicting a higher margin than 51% to 49%.
I then subtracted a few more percent since Van der Bellen won in the previous election, and Austria has never had a far right president. So my final prediction was 56%. Now I'm updating my forecast to be more confident since the polls are still about the same, and it is closer to the election. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrian_presidential_election,_2016#Opinion_polls)
I'm making a small update to my forecast to be 58% in favor of Norbert

But could it be that the election being held on the second Sunday of the Advent season (and all those holiday decorations) will warm hearts of the undecided and elect Van der Bellen by a slight margin?

A just-completed poll by the Oesterreich newspaper among likely voters nationwide showed Hofer leading Van der Bellen by a slim margin of 51 to 49 percent – in short, a reversal of the numbers in their original May showdown. The same poll showed that if parliamentary elections were called, Hofer’s Freedom Party would emerge triumphant with 35 percent of the vote, followed by the two parties that now govern Austria in a “grand coalition:” the Social Democrats at 26 percent and the People’s (conservative) Party at 19 percent.

The Austrian Presidential election is being rerun following a very close vote earlier this year, in which Van Der Bellen won. Recent polls indicate a marginal win for Hofer though the result is so close as to be meaningless.  Given the largely ceremonial role of the Austrian President, this vote is more likely to be used as a protest vote than in a full election. Hofer's FPO is typical of ant-establishment populist parties in Europe. Van Der Bellen himself is a Green-supported candidate and has not set the world alight. His strong pro-European stance will likely make the vote a proxy for dissatisfaction with the EU. Austria is one of the most Eurosceptic countries in the EU: https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2016/jun/23/is-britain-most-eurosceptic-country  Perceptions of unfairness over the original vote is likely to boost Hofer. Turnout is likely to be depressed due to voter apathy. Low turnout may well boost Hofer whose voters are more motivated to turn up.

BBC offers background on why Austrian constitutional court annulled the original vote, link here http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36681475

"Newsweek" article suggests "far right" candidate of the Freheitspartei, Hofer, is poisted to win the second go-round.  Link here http://www.newsweek.com/austria-presidential-election-freedom-party-poll-lead-re-run-far-right-486304

After Hungary and Colombia--these being only the most recent results that were unexpected, at least among me-- guessing about elections seems increasingly like a mug's game.  Still, one has to try.  On previous form, expect a big win for the Greens in Austria next week.

Austrians fed up with endless campaign as misfires force third vote in tight presidential race
Now postponed to Dec. 4, the election was itself a rerun of a spring national vote that was declared invalid after the razor-thin result could not be confirmed amid accusations of vote-rigging. That vote in May, furthermore, was the second round in Austria’s presidential election, meaning Austrians are now preparing to cast ballots for their head of state for the third time. Ahead of the Oct. 2 election, the Freedom Party's (FPO) Norbert Hofer is just ahead of his independent rival, Alexander Van der Bellen, who narrowly beat Hofer in a previous run-off vote in May that was annulled.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-austria-election-farright-idUSKCN1140QQ

This is going to be a close one.  Will have to keep my eye on the polls and betting markets closely.  Giving a slight lead to Hofer now given Europe's rightward anti-migrant shift. Also, escalating tensions between Austria and Hungary over migrants might give Hofer an edge by keeping the migrant issue salient. Of course, if Trump loses in the US elections, there might be a backlash against populist candidates in later elections (read in Austria). So, very high level of uncertainty ATM, but going to keep an eye on this one.

Deutche Welle reported that the new election date would be on 04/12 [1]. Wikipedia has a number of polls, the most recent on 24/09, that showed a marginal lead for Hoffer [2]. Polls reported at the end of August had also Hofer in the lead [3] & [4], where it was also mentioned that the undecided were high, but a percentage was not given. Under these conditions, a prediction is particularly hard. The odds appear practically even (accounting for the polls margin of error). Moreover, there is at least two months before the election, with a large number of voters who have not decided, and a significant contributing factor on what to vote for many would be emotional. This means that the result can go either way depending on the candidates' PR tactics and events that happen to take place  in the mean time (ranging from the plight of migrants to terrorist attacks), which will affect how many voters will be engaged to go to the ballot box in the first place and then also influence which candidate they will vote. Hence, at this point in time, an equal probability was assigned.  [1] http://www.dw.com/en/austria-postpones-presidential-election/a-19544471
[ 2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrian_presidential_election,_2016
[3] http://www.breitbart.com/london/2016/08/30/expert-predicts-hofer-win-austrian-presidential-re-run/
[4] http://www.reuters.com/article/us-austria-election-farright-idUSKCN1140QQ
Apparently the election will not upcome until December, but it's unlikely that this will affect the expected result.

Right, lets start from the bottom. Last time we did this there were only 30,000 votes in it. That's ~0.67% of all voters - well within the margin of error for polls. The irregularities in the vote were apparently great enough that there was the chance that they could have changed the outcome (although it was a very small chance). Previous to the last election there was a poll that had Hoffer leading by 6 points by Gallup. The likely voters, however, were split 50/50. Keeping with Gallup (in the hope that they haven't changed their methodology too much - yes I know, a flawed assumption) the most recent polls haven't mentioned likely voters, but they do have Hoffer leading by 2 points.   Given that polls haven't shown any voter apathy on either side and that we haven't had any likely voters polls recently (last one which talked about likely voters was back at the beginning of October) I'm going to hedge my bets.

Elections are postponed to December 4 (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-austria-election-poll-idUSKCN11O0DN?il=0)  Can the Freedom Party's candidate Norbert Hofer win? This postponement won't help Hofer at all. The delay may play better for Van der Bellen, however I will keep my forecast to Hofer. His side may be more motivated and the polls may not tell it all.
Sept. 15 Gallup poll continues to show Hofer up 51 - 49.

Polls are very close to 50-50 right now, an average of the last 4 gives Hofer an 0.5% edge.  However, heading into the May vote polls showed him with around a 3.5% margin, and lost the vote count by almost 1%. In the May vote, the percentage of voters vs the population in each district showed a strong positive correlation with Hofer's vote margin.  I don't know much about Austria's district level demographics, so it's entirely possible that this is because the districts which favored Van der Bellen have more children and immigrants who are not eligible to vote, but I'm guessing that this is only a partial explanation, and that turnout was indeed lower in those districts.  Assuming that very few people will actually change their vote from the previous round, Van der Bellen has a larger pool of potential voters to turnout and improve on his vote totals. Finally, a rerun of Vienna's second district resulted in a strong showing for the Green party.  They gained mostly at the expense of the SPO, but it still seems to be an indication that in reruns, the Greens might have an advantage against the FPO.
http://www.thelocal.at/20160919/green-party-wins-election-re-run-in-viennas-leopoldstadt With these considerations I think Van der Bellen has a decent edge despite the media narrative.

Recent polls are variable and delays may work to Van der Bellen an advantage.

If any country is going to vote a populist right wing leader president it will be Austria. First vote should also have gotten some Austrians used to the idea already. I predict a narrow victory by 2 or 3 percent. lets see.

The recent polls showing a small lead for Hofer (52-48) are subject to a decent margin of error. Since the Brexit vote, many countries have seen a shift to more pro-EU. This supports van der Bellen. Sofar in 2016 the inflow of refugees has been small so less on peoples mind than earlier this, this also supports van der Bellen.

I think the very tight result in May will change towards Hofer for two reasons. A) FPÖs victory at the supreme court, which ordered that the election has to be repeated. But more important: B) More acts of terrorism in Europe, moving public opinion even more towards anti-refugee policies.
Because of how close the vote was previously more people should turn out to vote. Far right parties tend to do best when there is a low turnout.

Most recent poll, Gallup on August 2, showed Hofer at 52%, one point higher than he got in early July.  Van der Bellen got 48%.  Urban, educated voters continue to overwhelmingly back  Van der Bellen, while manual workers and rural voters support Hofer.   The matter of the 9 refugees accused of raping a German woman on new year's eve is having an effect on public opinion.  Hofer called for a ban on burqas this week, has advocated for blocking Turkey into the EU, and threatened to push for the country to leave the EU.  That is bound to get him a lot of attention and press but we need to look deeper to figure out if the conditions are there for it to hold and propel him.  So far, it seems so.   But we should also consider that such controversial issues get a lot of media attention and a lot of people talking and might contribute to giving an inflated impression of how people will vote.  This week, the country's foreign minister, Sebastian Kurz from the OVP party) called for an obligatory 1-euro jobs for refugees as part of the country's immigrant integration proposals.  He also said that the issue of the burqa needs to be discussed as a "full body veil hinder integration" He called the burqa "not a religious symbol but a symbol for a counter society."  It will be interesting to see how the public reacts to this and to the integration proposals.  It could be a good indicator of how the election might lean.  Notably, 3 French cities have recently banned the burkini swimsuits saying they defy French laws of secularism.  France already has a ban on niqabs and burqas in public.  From what I could find on the web, Van der Bellen seems to be running a more organized campaign.  The recall election is supposed to leave no doubt of the legitimacy of the process but you can find many tweets and posts on social media sites from nationalists using the Austria case as confirmation that the US election is rigged.  Just an interesting observation on the trend in different countries.   If Austria votes for Hofer, it will be the first country in Europe with a far right government.  The Freedom Party was once described "as a party of former Nazis for former Nazis.” To see chilling tweets in support of Hofer that also say that Nazism isn't bad is what makes me forecast in favor of Van der Bellen winning.  But that rationale is also part of what made me forecast Brexit would not happen so I need to keep that in mind. assuming "none of the above" means another disputed overturned election, The rise of the right is always underestimated in polls and mainstream analysis (just look at Brexit). This is a close one, since Austria superficially seems less pro-nationalist than other European countries (caveat: I am american and so just going by news articles not experience). Do anti-immigrant voters think the election was stolen by Van der Bellen and now will retaliate? Or do more moderate voters who were on the fence see a close election and decide they will vote against Hofer? Tough to assess the psychology here, but in all giving a slight edge to Hofer.
It's a sour mood all over the world.

Van der Bellen won the last election by a mere 31,000 votes.  My prediction is that the Trump effect in the US (which right now is looking likely to produce negative results in the polls), and even the aftermath of Brexit, will mobilize more people to support Van der Bellen.  Terrorism or further issues with refugees in the country between now and October may give Hofer the edge he needs but I think a lot will depend on the support either candidate may get from the establishment.  NOTE:  
In April, for the first round of the election, Hofer and his Freedom Party of Austria, got the most votes. 
Van der Bellen, running as an independent, came in second.  The candidates of the two governing parties,Social Democratic and Austrian People's parties, came in 4th and 5th place respectively, behind independent candidate Irmgard Griss who came in 3rd place.   Because no candidate received over 50% of the vote, Hofer and Van der Bellen went to a second round in May.  RE-RUN ELECTION - 
The second round of voting  were annulled after the Austrian Constitutional Court found that electoral rules "had been disregarded in 14 out of 20 contested administrative districts (from a total of 117), resulting in over 77,900 absentee votes being improperly counted."  There are no proof or indication of votes having been fraudulently manipulated.  POLLS:
Gallup poll published in Austria on 8/2 showed Hofer at 52% vs 48% for Van der Bellen. NOTE:  
This election is the first since WWII where an Austrian president has not been backed by either the People's or the Social Democratic parties.  We should be watching if there is any difference in their support or endorsement of the candidates.

The poll published by the Österreich paper on Sunday (31 July) showed the midpoint of the wide range of support for Hofer at 52% — one point higher than a poll in early July found — versus 48% for van der Bellen.
https://www.euractiv.com/section/elections/news/right-wing-nationalist-set-to-win-rerun-austrian-presidential-race/
Alexander Van der Bellen narrowly won last time. I think that supporters of the other two main parties are more likely to rally to him this time.

Austria has produced some less than stellar political leaders over the past several decades, starting in let's say April 1889, even when they went for a former UN SecGen. One feels a bit funky predicting that they will not keep up the tradition, so I'll probably  start to move up more on Hofer as more polls come in.  This is another one where it is important to separate expectation from aspiration.

It appears that the anti immigrant sentiments which almost give the previous election to Hofer has only increased with the recent events in Germany.  While his election may not be overwhelming he does seems to have the voting majority agreeing with his policy of restricting further large scale immigration and use of Austria as a transition point into Germany.

I think key question here may be if public think Van der Bellen had anything to do with the manipulation of the election or if he benefitted from it, if not I think majority who voted for him will do so again as they will feel their voice was not heard, then he just needs to pick up some of the other votes, so starting slightly in his favor though poles slightly in favor of Hofer

Prior to the 1st round, Hofer consistently  rose in the polls, out performed in the first round and gained almost an another 15% in the cancelled 2nd round.  The security issues in the EU seem to be in his favor.
